title: NEMA 17 Stepper Motor Optical Breadboard Mount

description.text:
This is a NEMA 17 stepper motor mount that can be used on an optical breadboard for experiments and prototyping.

The distance between the mounting slots is 2 inches to accommodate an optical breadboard with 1 inch hole spacing.

I have made two of them so far (2016/07/29) for two stepper motors and they are well balanced and have a decent tolerance on the mounting holes and mounting slots. Mounting slots can accommodate possibly up to 1/4"-20 bolts and smaller. (Have not tested with 1/4"-20 but I think they should work).

I will be coming out with other mounting options and hardware for setting up structures and equipment for conducting experiments.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.18mm

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

Used Flashprint as my previous slicing software but decided to get Simplify3D. I had some issues with my printer but I have resolved them now so I will post more stats in the near future.

title: FabscanPi Camera Mount For New Case

description.text:
The new software version of the fabscan - the fabscan pi - uses a raspberry-pi 2 and a pi-cam.
Watterrott designed a little board that has a LED-ring build in.

If you allready have an 50mm LED ring - you can use this thing to fix the camera and the ring in the new case.

The LED-ring I use has a diameter of 50 mm and four holes in a distance of 33 mm each.

I add the FrreCad-File so you can change it accordingly to your needs.

title: Porygon Pokemon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
ポリゴン
Number: 137
Type: Normal
Evolves from: None
Evolves into: Porygon2

No glue needed, all parts are friction fit. The overhang on the eyes needs good cooling to prevent PLA curling, the head may need some support on the "chin". The pupils are very small and can optionally be left out. The other parts are straight forward to print, brim may be used to increase bed adhesion.

A secret compartment can be accessed by removing the head.

comments.text: I'm having difficulty getting the pupils into the eyes. Do you have any helpful tips for that?
If your slicer does scaling well, try knocking it down a few percent. they are such a small part that I tried a lot and found a nearly perfect fit! (3-4% smaller I think)

Small parts like the pupils are likely to not come out pretty. I had to clean/cut them down with a sharp knife until I could press them in, it was not easy because they are so small.
If you can not make them fit i would recommend printing a solid flat piece of PLA/ABS and cut out the pupil shape with scissors.

description.text:
I have realized that there are quite a bit of difference between the colors of different filament brands. Opacity, intensity, tone, and florescence are some of the properties i have found differ between brands.

There are two zones, one large where you can write down the name of the filament and a small area with 0.1 mm, 0.2 mm, and 0.3 mm thick areas so you can compare how thin sections will look. The hole is 4 mm.

[7 of Aug 17]
Added a couple of models with 0.4 / 0.8 / 1.2 mm as well as 0.5 / 1.0 / 1.5 mm to match the wall thickness of common nozzles. Print with och close to 100% infill to get a realistic opacity. Also changed the hole size to 5mm. Leaving the old one up if you already used it and want your new ones exactly the same.

Designed with OnShape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/b94e9ec9aee632c4fb8631e7/w/708a8fcb904cff13521875fb/e/dcfb36abf0dee5eefba083d8

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Make sure all your layers are 0.1 mm to make full use of the transparency window.

comments.text: I use a permanent marker, no particular brand. On dark colors i use a cheap silver pen off eBay, not as good as a permanent marker but have worked for me.

comments.text: Hi when I set the resolution in cura to 0.1mm and look at the layers, it would only print the part where it's 0.3mm thick. Maybe I should try it out but I think it would not print anything in the front. What do you think could be wrong?
comments.author: pregnantbird

comments.text: Sounds tricky, I'm afraid I don't know the answer. The only things i can think of is that you have two settings contradicting them selves, or you are trying to print it on it's edge. Printing with 0.1mm layers aren't really that uncommon so it shouldn't really be a problem. What version of Cura are you using and what printer?
comments.author: pregnantbird

comments.text: The model is flat on the ground as it is normally imported. I am using Cura 2.6.2 on a Creality CR10 but with the settings for Ultimaker2 it looks the same. Maybe i should just try printing it instead of thinking theoretically about it :D
comments.author: ornotermes

comments.text:
After looking it up, the default in Cura is that the first layer is 0.3mm and anything thinner will be ignored, to change it you will need to:
Toggle Print Setup to Custom. Hover over Quality and click the gear. Check the box next to Initial Layer Height and close the window. Now you can click Quality and change Initial Layer Height to 0.1.
But expect it to be a bit harder to print with so you probably want to change it back for regular prints.
comments.author: pregnantbird

comments.text: Thanks :) This works!!
comments.author: ornotermes

comments.text: This is brilliant. I'm going to get a whole set of my colors printed, thanks
comments.author: Taclys

comments.text: This is brilliant. I'm going to get a whole set of my colors printed, thanks
comments.author: Taclys

comments.text: Any advice on how to get them off the platform without the .1 mm area breaking due to the adhesion?
comments.author: ReqPro

comments.text: I think it depends a bit on you print surface as well as the filament, but i think the key is to not rip it off. I use a Cricut spatula (a very thin one) and slide it in from the thick end, when i get to the .1mm are I work around it and finish by slowly work my way under it. If you don't have a thin spatula you could try something else like paper or a sewing thread. Hope you find a good solution.
comments.author: ReqPro

comments.text: Makes sense... I am using kapton tape on a heated glass bed, so the adhesion is crazy - also using 3DPrima PLA filament which is pretty brittle, so that doesn't help either.... I don't have a spatula, but I do have a box-shape exacto blade that I tried, but it ended up just cutting the filament when it was slightly stretched from trying to come off the platform.... I'll try the sewing thread approach, that actually sounds like a great idea.
comments.author: ornotermes

comments.text: Sewing thread worked absolutely brilliantly! Thanks for the advice and your time :D
comments.author: ReqPro

comments.text: Great, nice to hear it worked.

title: Pokemon Go Aimer - universal - tested on Sony Xperia Z

description.text:
UPDATE: After a lot of testing and redesigning I have found my finale version:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1702184

UPDATE: I have uploaded another version, where the thickness of your smart phone doesn´t matter that much anymore :

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696283

With this Aimer, the button problem with the galaxy S models is solved!

UPDATE: Added a picture with the distances. This might help scaling the STL for your smart phone thickness

UPDATE: Replaced the STL by a aligned version. Should now perfecly place on your build plate.

UPDATE: The Hard Button for Samsung Galaxy models is an issue. You should add a hole on this Position. SOLVED: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696283

This is a Remix of the Pokemon Go Aimer from Jcach. I have triied to make it universal for most Smart Phones with a Thickness of around 8 mm. The idea behind is, that the distance between clip end and front is a little lower than on the bottom.

Print it and tell me in the comment section, if it fits for your mobile! For Sony Xperia Z it´s working.

Position like in the Pictures.

3 Shells/0.2mm/30% Infill.

Print time: > 1h
Slicer: S3D

MAKE SAVE, THAT THE FRONT SURFACE LIES FLAT ON THE BED! (there are some 1degr angles included to make it work)

title: Storage box for bookmarks / "Page Tracker" ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:113991 )

description.text:
I have recently printed a bunch of excellent bookmarks / Page Trackers ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:113991) by the user Alejoo ( http://www.thingiverse.com/Alejoo ). I soon noticed though that they might get lost around the house so I have decided to make a spring driven dispenser with a magnetic mount ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1688487 ) which now I have put to both bathrooms and places where my family members like to read. Later it appeared to me that I need to have some spare bookmarks printed and stored to refill the dispenser. So here is a remix of the design into the simple storage box.

I have designed this box for the PLA but finally printed it in HIPS (was lazy to swap filaments), which is dimensionally more exact. Therefore you could see some of the electrical tape in the attached pictures to make a cap fit more tightly. But with PLA (I tried it on the dispenser) cap snaps on perfectly without any additional aid.

Printer:

Raise3D N2 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Printed in HIPS.
Bed (BuildTak) temperature 110 ℃
Nozzle 235 ℃
No cooling and closed printing environment (important for HIPS)

author: glassy

print_settings.Notes:: Don't print the rubber filament too hot otherwise it won't bridge as well.

title: Moto G4 Plus Phone Cover (Rubber Filament)

description.text:
This is a cover for a Lenovo Moto G4 Plus phone. It's designed in openScad. I'm afraid the code is horrible as there was a lot of trial and error changes made. The measurements and shape were developed by trial and error.

Note that dimensions suit rubber filament which can be stretched slightly for a snug fit. The openings for power, earphone socket, volume and power buttons have a thin membranes to act as a supports. Use a sharp knife or cutters to cut the holes out.

The large hole in the back cover is where I stick and address label on the phone (in case I lose it).

I plan to try a PLA or ABS version soon. I suspect the design will have to change a bit to get the phone in 'cause it won't stretch.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Migbot Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layers, 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Don't print the rubber filament too hot otherwise it won't bridge as well.

Clean up

I've found that rubber filament is quite "stringy" and doesn't retract cleanly. So expect to end up with a bit of tidying up of loose threads. Also the overhangs are unsupported and quite ambitious. You could be a few "hung" threads that need to be cut.

Designed in openScad

Ok. So I started with the right intentions of well written code. After a few iterations the code got messier and worse. Sorry! Please don't expect the thing to scale correctly with parameter changes.

These are 3 things: spool holder for 60 mm filament spools, rod holder for universal ball bearing spool holders and nema17 motor holder for bowden setup.

Sometimes my drink bottles fall out of the side pockets on my backpack. The bottles get bigger and the elastic on my old backpack is getting weaker.

So a little thing is in order. Designed in openscad and printed in PLA.

Oh - the little tabs are mouse ears to keep it sticking to the build plate. Break them off when printing is complete.

This part is designed to allow you to adjust the position of the proximity sensor on the Reach 3D printer. Tried it out last night and it works, took 3 tries to get the filament to stick correctly. There are two parts to print, use the wood screw from the original kit to clamp the part to the sensor. You will need a M3x40mm screw, two M3 nuts and a washer. See the photos for assembly.

You will need to flip the Clamp Holder when printing so the flat is on the bed.

(August 8th edit: the clamp_holder has been updated with the new hole location)

I drilled a new hole the same place but "higher" and it worked. Forgot to update the model. I am traveling this week so will not be able to update till I get back. If you can mod it by drilling it should do it. You don't have to be exact.
comments.author: TheGusman

comments.text: Ah, no worries, I thought I was  doing something wrong, I can eyeball it and drill it, and since it is adjustable I just need to be close. Still a great design, I just need to figure out why my sensor works when it is at an angle, but is inconsonsistent when perpendicular to the bed.
comments.author: chan_man

comments.text: The new design has been uploaded, if you had already printed one, just drill a new hole. Thanks for printing this.
comments.author: TheGusman

comments.text: Thanks.. I was having issues getting the first layer to stick and to reset the sensor, you would have to loosen the nut and screw make the adjustment and see what happens. This worked the first time. It is a great kit, take your time putting it together. Make sure you wire up the fan to be always on, it does help.
comments.author: chan_man

comments.text: Nice idea!  I'm still piecing the kit together, but that stood out as the part I liked least on the carriage.  Your design goes a long way towards addressing the situation.
comments.author: WayTooManyHobbies

This was inspired by user schlotzz Fridge Magnet On/Off Switch. I designed mine in Tinkercad and made slots to insert a HarborFreight magnet. This didn't require any glue as the magnet fits tight in the slot.

It works well to hold things to the fridge.
The Magnet used is here: http://bit.ly/1ID1nNo

I printed it on my MP Select Mini but its so small it can fit on any 3D printer.
No supports required.

comments.text: Great design, fit the HF magnets perfectly. I ended up extruding the front and back faces 0.5mm in MeshMixer to get my slicer(craftware) to recognize the slots.

description.text:
This rope light hook can use either a standard drywall screw or your apartment-living-wall-friendly command strips to hang up rope lights around ceilings, cupboards, windows, door frams, and just about anywhere else you would like to put these connectable strings of soft, glowing lights. The ones pictured are obviously the command strip version and are working very well.
Superglue on a magnet and they also make a fantastic Pilot brand pen holder for the side of the fridge or locker door. This thing was made with Tinkercad.

So The Third Part Of This adventure to make
Moduler Maidens. This Time I tried making
Her Click Together .I didn't quite achieve That
She Still Needs Gluing .But She is Easier to

title: Qidi magnetic door stop; 10mm magnet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just another door latch for the QIDI printer. Tolerances are quite tight, so I printed in ABS and it was snug but useable after cool-down.

Takes a 10mm disk magnet with a 2mm depth, press to fit. There is 1mm material between the magnet/handle and the QIDI printer body/window. I was able to use the original mounting screws.

Note: oh right - I made the through-holes for the handle for 3mm screws instead of 4mm, but they ream out to 4mm easily.

title: Rostock Max spool "cartridge" system
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this a long time ago because I thought the "wooden arm" on the Rostock Max was, well, crappy. I designed this to fit in the same slots that the wooden spool holder arm fits into. As a system of cartridges so you could easily change out spools and have them ride super smooth on bearings.

Use this with 5/16ths threaded rod, nuts and 608 "skate" bearings. (That you can often get used for free at your local skate shop. They won't be "perfect" but they will be just fine for this use.)

You can see I have quite an assortment myself.

I included a few hub sizes here here, sorry I don't use Openscad or I would add a parametric one. There are already several parametric spool hubs out there, like these:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27748
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25843
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1405931

Thanks!

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are important for the overhang at the top of the part. Nothing else needs supports. I used the stock QIDI turbo fan. Infill did not prove to be significant throughout my prototype prints; 30% works fine.

title: QIDI rear mounted dual blower for active print cooling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
FIRST THING FIRST: this needs a 5mm shim on the Y-axis in order to allow clearance for the blowers and assembly behind the print head. This is critical because when both the build plate is raised all the way up, and the Y-axis is all the way to the rear of the printer, there is no clearance between this blower and Z-axis bearings as the X-axis jogs past.

The Z-axis bearings are wider than the Z-axis rods, so once the Z-axis bearings are lower than the blower assembly, there are no more clearance issues. You can do without the shim if you modify your start script and build plan accordingly, but I personally strongly recommend the shim.

Ok now that that's over with:
This accomplishes 3 things I really wanted.
First, both print heads have cooling so I do not have to keep switching spools based on cooling needs.
Second, each print head has its own blower. I found that simply using the stock blower to cool both heads at once was giving me sub-par cooling and warping issues.
Third, REAR MOUNTED. To me, this is way better than blocking the view of the print via a front mounted assembly.
Bonus stuff - I opted to use blowers rather than fans because these printers simply do not have the space to smoothly transition from the large diameter of a fan down to the small diameter cooling ducts. All the cooling assemblies I see that use fans sharply transition to a small set of ducts directly in front of the fan, reducing the capability of the fans. Blowers, due to their design, higher static pressure, smaller exit, are better suited to this application of forcing air into these smaller cooling assemblies. That's my take on the situation and I do not have test data to back this up - so take it with a grain of salt.

I purchased blowers here :http://www.ebay.com/itm/262351228368?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
They are the same manufacturer and dimensions as the stock QIDI blower. They have slightly higher current draw and probably higher CFM.

Also, googling this will put you in the right direction: 24v 5015s blower

The main criteria are

  • 50x50x15mm - some are wider than 15mm so be careful
  • 24v
  • I chose .14 amp blowers while the stock was .11 or .12 from memory.

Blowers are simply wired in parallel; plugged into the original QIDI harness.

Another note - the two blowers are isolated from each other, so i suppose you could use this with only one blower while waiting for another in the mail, or if you simply want a rear mounted blower.

Mounting: tabs interface with the top of the X-axis carriage, but allow translation left & right (along the X-axis). I left it this way as this is my beta product if you will, and in case there were clearance issues. There aren't, and I simply affixed a small piece of double stick foam tape to the same surface as the tabs. This snugs everything up nicely and I didn't even remove the backing to expose the adhesive to the print head carriage.

Printer:

QIDI

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Supports are important for the overhang at the top of the part. Nothing else needs supports. I used the stock QIDI turbo fan. Infill did not prove to be significant throughout my prototype prints; 30% works fine.

comments.text:
Great design. Thanks!
How are the blowers fastened to the carriage? I don't see the way you attached them.
comments.author: MPeter

comments.text: How were you able to plug in both blowers & have them powered separately?  I have a Qidi Tech I and I really want to upgrade my fan.  Looking at it I only see one wire for the existing fan.
comments.author: giggiibear8

comments.text:
You're right, only 1 plug. I soldered 2 blowers in parallel and plugged them both into the one harness plug. They cannot be controlled separately.
The fans don't draw much power so I was comfortable doing this.
comments.author: giggiibear8

comments.text: Ok, thanks.   Did the blowers come with the adapter that lets you plug both into the Qidi?
comments.author: whited3

comments.text:
No, there was no adapter. I used the plug from the original QIDI blower.
I cut the plugs off 2 blowers, and then soldered their wires in parallel with the original QIDI blower plug that plugs into the harness. It's probably very unlikely you'll find an adapter, but I could be wrong. Soldering was the simplest way to go for me.
comments.author: giggiibear8

comments.text: Can I ask how have you attached the shim?
comments.author: Ridley

comments.text: Oh good question... I used double sided tape - the 3m heavy duty type which may have been overkill. A more elegant solution surely exists, but this has been working well for me.
comments.author: Ridley

comments.text: Do you have to limit the y-axis afterwards then when you use the shim? (Sorry for this noob question)
comments.author: whited3

comments.text: If you mean reducing the y axis travel, then yes it would be best to do so, especially if you are printing near the edge of the plate. In Simplify 3d, I reduced the size of my build plate smaller by 5mm according to the 5mm shim.

This is a container designed to fit 2L and similar bottle caps to allow it to be waterproof. Smoothing of the top surface may be necessary. The idea is that this will be utilized for something such as hiking to hold a map, or matches, or something along those lines. I plan on printing it tonight so I will upload a picture and any updates if I need to. Feel free to create whatever you want on the case/from this.

UPDATE:
It works! I tested it with a cap from Kikoman soy sauce and a cap from a bottle of wine, it wasn't compatible with milk carton caps due to the inner lip of the plastic, but should be compatible with soda bottle caps. I didn't have matches or anything so I put candy in it for the picture. I will hopefully add more features soon.

Monoprice Duplicator I3

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

20
Just add a bottle cap and your container should be waterproof.

Design Details

I utilized solidworks and the GPI standard to create this design, the thread info can be found at gpi.org and the thread is gpi 400, without the optional piece and extending slightly further.

So, you've probably got a few extra spools lying around. Me too. I use my 3d printer to make lots of miniatures for tabletop gaming, and I like to have those painted. By drilling a few holes, sized appropriately for whichever brand of paint you use, you can make a rack suitable for paints. Smaller holes can be used to accommodate brushes, or an empty paint container with no lid. Additionally, small plastic cups, the kind you use for the bathroom, fit perfectly into the center hole for brush cleaning water. Finally, if you set these up correctly, they stack.

I've included an stl file to give you an idea of what it should look like. I've laid out 1.5 in and .25 in holes for 10 paint containers and 10 brushes. I suppose you could print it, but why wouldn't you just use an old spool instead?

Enjoy.

title: Y axis clamp for Geetech Prusa i3

description.text:
My Geetech Prusa i3 came with an aluminium block that the y axis belt had to be attached to by drilling a couple of holes in the belt and screwing a bolt through the belt into the block. I was never happy with the design as it always seemed to pull the belt slightly to one side and too high and adjusting the tension was impossible.

When the Y axis tensioner/bearing seized I decided to get a better quality bearing and, with it, a better quality belt and didn't want to have the same tensioning issues again. I based the design, instead, on the clamp that I used for the X-carriage as that has worked really well without any problems.

The attached .scad file has all the size variables at the top which should allow the depth of the clamp and everything else to be customised. The attached .stl file is set up for my Geetech Prusa i3 but may work for similar designs without customisation. If anyone wants a .stl with different parameters and doesn't want to modify the .scad file themselves, let me know !

Printer:

Geetech Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this with 20% infill and 1.2 shell and top/bottom widths with it laid on it's side, as oriented in the .stl file.

Add captive M3 nuts

As this is replacing a drilled and tapped aluminium block, you will need to add 2 x M3 nuts into the provided captive nut positions. On my print I had the nut diameter set a bit tight so had to use pliers to squeeze the nuts into position. I've added an additional 0.1 mm clearance in the current .scad file and .stl

You will probably also need some slightly longer M3 bolts than the ones used in the original.

description.text:
These enclosures have the same inner and outer dimensions as their Hammond counter parts. The holes in the lid are not going through the whole lid, instead only 3mm into it.

This boxes are intended to be used with magnets as closing mechanics instead of the screws.
The Body part takes four 3mm Diameter and 10mm height screws. The top takes four 4mm Diameter 3mm height magnets.

Those same magnets may be used with the original Hammond boxes since they fit the holes, but they need to be glued into place. With the 3D printed part they should simply press fit. With the original boxes you should also consider a 6mm Diameter 1mm height magnet to cover the magnet in the lid

Testing sizes:
First print test.stl and make sure the wall sizes and holes for the magnet fit your printer settings. If they do, good you can use all the available boxes.

Each box has the following stls:

  • Both: Body and lid
  • Body: only the body
  • Lid: only the lid

If they do not, open the customizer and adjust the values as needed. The offsets are offsets from the original size.

The attached stl's are rendered from the customizers default settings.

Available Boxes:
1550:

  • 1550A
  • 1550B
  • 1550P
  • 1550Q

1590:

  • 1590A
  • 1590B
  • 1590G

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Yes

Supports:

No

0.3

Notes:

Default settings and STL's are what I use and where my magnets fit perfectly.

This is actually my yesterday's evening-hack. It's redundant, because there are many bearings in thingiverse and it's of no use because I have loads of proper cheap Chinese metal bearings of different sizes and I guess that you have some, too. I just made ist to distract me from some other project, a heat-exchanger. Anyway, I share it for fun. Maybe someone likes the look of my rounded edges or maybe someone gets some inspiration from the code, like not to work with the basic object directives so much when constructing objects but to increase use of linear_extrude() and rotate_extrude() with parameterized polygons stuck together with concat(). A good practice could be changing the function kreislinie(), that returns the 2D-points of an arc, so that start- and end-angle can be overwritten by start- and end-height,
This is also an experiment to give Error messages and Object-Information to the user via text-output in customizer. Unfortunately newline-characters aren't rendered as such, so lines may get too long. Disable the option view_sectioned before you create your stl. It's default is yes, because you should use it first, to check if everything looks good inside. Try view_info in the in the Design-Check tab to see the overhang-angle of the chamfer to adjust your slicer not to support this overhang but the balls.
The "au" setting reduces the number ob balls by virtually enlarging the balls by this percentage and looking up the value of the largest inner circle that smaller than the diameter of this inner circle. Don't set this too high, as the bearing may then fall apart if all the balls are one one side.
I haven't made a good print of this, yet. The balls I print (avoiding the phrase "my ..") are too much the shape of a pill. For me, balls are generally something difficult to print I'll try less infill or less heatbed, next time. Of course it's best practice to find printing parameters that create good balls, but itt maybe interesting, to experiment with the shape of the balls, anyway. Please give me advice in the comments if you know more about printing balls, than me.
So next step will be to make the shape of the balls customizable using rotate_extrude with a parametrized polygon, so I (or you) can try any instance of cylinder with rounded corners including ball, oval and cylinder.

See also:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40559

History:
2016-07-28: Initial hack
2016-07-29: Published it.
2016-07-30: Changed the recursive lookup-function, that searches a given inner diameter and finds the corresponding number of surrounding circles, to a function that calculates the value.
Before:
V_innerradiusses = [ for(i=[0:1:100]) ((i>2)?(sqrt(1+sqr(tan(90-(360/i/2))))-1):0) ];
function findbiggestsmaller(V, x, i) = (V[i+1] > x) ? i : findbiggestsmaller(V, x, i+1);
Now:
function balls_by_ri(ri,rb) = round((180/(90-atan(sqrt(sqr((ri/rb+1))-1))))-0.5);

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50%
On my next attempt I'll try to rework the upsides of the balls on the heatbed, when the balls still sit in their supports.

title: Phasma Blaster - Parts for Flat outline

description.text:
My daughter wanted to dress up as Phasma from Star Wars, we decided to make a blaster the right scale for her. These are the parts that we stuck to an MDF outline to make it look more realistic.

Parts are scaled for the blaster we made - the approx 12.5mm thick MDF outline is around 50cm long, I drew it freehand from photo references but I wasn't super careful. I cut the shape out with a jigsaw and smoothed it a little (remember to use a good dust mask). If you make it bigger you'll probably need to scale the parts.

Printer:

mini kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layers

Infill:

I used 20%, anything else should work

Notes:

I used a brim for most parts

To Fix to MDF

I used generic CA (cyanoacrylate "superglue") to fix the parts to the MDF outline. It looks like it won't stick but does if enough is used to seal the very porous surface.

OpenSCAD files & sources

All parts were made in OpenSCAD: sources are included along with SVG and DXF files that are extruded for some parts.

print_settings.Notes:: These parts are designed to be printed on their side. To make sure they wouldn't fall over, I printed a raft around the parts, but I think this isn't necessary. Support also is not necessary, unless your printer has trouble bridging. There is one exception: the coutout and bracket in the BracketCutout part need support material. The fit is loose; if you want them to snap together more firmly, consider adding 0,05 to 0,1mm all around (if your slicer can do this). However, you'll need to secure it more permanently to use it on your bicycle anyway.

description.text:
Racing bikes are one of the best modes of transport. But wet roads can be annoying: you'll get a fountain of water spraying upwards from the tyres. A storebought mudguard/fender is either ugly, heavy, impractical, or just unpersonal, so I wanted another solution.

Meet the Modular Mudguard!
Pick and mix the desired modules (see the STL Name Guide in the pictures) to compose your perfect layout. You'll never have to change clothes after a rainy commute again. If you have other module ideas or if you want any changes, look below for info on customized parts.

If you make one, please please share the results!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,4x0,1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These parts are designed to be printed on their side. To make sure they wouldn't fall over, I printed a raft around the parts, but I think this isn't necessary. Support also is not necessary, unless your printer has trouble bridging. There is one exception: the coutout and bracket in the BracketCutout part need support material. The fit is loose; if you want them to snap together more firmly, consider adding 0,05 to 0,1mm all around (if your slicer can do this). However, you'll need to secure it more permanently to use it on your bicycle anyway.

Bar attachment
  • I bought stock mudguard bars that connect to the mudguard and frame. It wouldn't be too much issue to make them yourself, but you probably want to make sure it won't rattle when riding the bike.
  • Since my bike doesn't have attachment loops on the frame, I also made my own simple connection brackets. They're customly dimensioned for my bike to the millimeter (11mm and 16mm); if anyone is interested in them, let me know and I'll publish them on Thingiverse as well.
Fixing the parts

There's many ways to do this.

  • The easiest would be a superglue or (if using ABS) acetone.
  • You can also drill small holes through the connection parts and use tiny bolts and nuts. This way, you can change to composition to your liking. However, make sure to use locknuts; everything will vibrate violently, and normal nuts will definitely come loose. Also consider using washers.
  • Rivet together for that industrial look. Again, use washers to avoid destroying the plastic.
  • Weld together by friction welding with filament & multitool (video will follow).

I used friction welding, because it's awesome, fast, and definitely permanent. I made a video that I will share shortly, to give an idea of the very simple process. Black isn't the best colour for friction welding due to the discolouration, but still. Try it!

Weight

The weight of the Neutral part is 16 grams (PLA, 20% infill, 0,8mm wall thickness).
Both end caps are about 8 grams, and the bracket parts are <20 grams. This means the front mudguard (6 modules) in my composition weighs about 80 grams, and the back mudguard (7 modules) weighs <100 grams. This does not include any nuts, bolts or bars.

Dimensions

This mudguard has been designed for a standard racing bike:

  • 700x23C
  • 23-622 / 17-622

The width of the mudguard is 37mm. At my front fork, there wasn't space to mount the mudguard high enough to not hit the tyre, so that's why I had to create the cutout part.

Each section is exactly 20° of a full 360° circle, or 1/18th. The cap ends are 10°.

The distance from mudguard surface to the center axle of the hole:

  • Bracket: 8,55mm
  • BracketCutout: 13mm

• As you can see, I removed my hand brakes and switched to a coaster brake. I am not sure if the parts will fit with all brake pad compositions, but if you try it and it fails, let me know and I'll see if I can make a fitting design.
  • The brackets are also custom designed for my own bike, so again, if they don't fit, let me know and I can see if I can easily adapt the model.
  • I will not share the original CAD model, but I am usually really fast with requests, as long as you give me a good description!

comments.text: Wow, that's really cool. I had thought about doing something like this but really wasn't sure how to approach it. Looks like you figured it out pretty well. Good instructions, as well. Looking forward to trying this out, thank you!
comments.author: cmh

comments.text: Thanks! Please be advised that in this setup, the PLA actually wasn't stiff enough to arch the entire distance between the supports on the back mudguard, so it rests lightly on my tyre. Not a big issue, but if I had to do it again, I'd make an extra support beam midway.

title: O scale pallet Remix - Group of 9 (or 8)

description.text:
I don't know if this even really qualifies as a remix or not... What I did was take the excellent O scale pallet made by bnoggle and duplicated it so that nine are printed together.

It's quicker when your trying to print a bunch of them.

Update: I printed this (Medium quality - 250 microns, Medium fill, raft) and, as can be seen in the photograph, I got 8 really nice pallets and some strange, cross-hatched thing in the centre. I do not know why. I may have to fix the file and remove the centre one entirely, saving on filament, and change the name. I would be curious to know if anyone can tell what happened to that centre pallet.
2nd Update: I'm not sure what causes the centre pallet to incorrectly printed. I have tried increasing the distance between pallets to see if that is the problem. No change. So I have modified my original file and removed the centre pallet altogether (8_pallets.stl). You can try the 9 pallet version still, you may have better luck. On the upside, I now have a healthy collection of tiny pallets!

description.text:
Balis-Kit is literally a ballistic kit to assemble and calibrate. This Small desk catapult is able to provide non-lethal kinetic energy to an object willing to fly. The interest of this kit lies in the fact that you can adjust :

  • The power by using different types of elastic or different position of the elastics along the arm
  • The trajectory angle by changing the position of the arresting screw
    (See post printing section)

By assembling this project you will gain access to an interesting experimentation tool to discover:

  • Physic through elastic potential energy and kinetic energy of the projectile.
  • The art of desk war strategy
  • Not to forget the ballistic equations with second order polynomial that comes with Newton’s law

For the propulsion you can use different types of elastics.

You will need

  • 10 M3 screw 30mm long for the maximum.
  • 12 M3 bolts
  • Elastics
  • Gum makes an intresting projectile.

=================== !!! WARNING !!! ===================
Please send soft material like gum. Metallic material are interesting because of their density but they might break things or hurt people.
=================== !!! WARNING !!! ===================

description.text:
A pair of mounting brackets that will allow you to mount your Asus MB168B monitor to a wall or other vertical surface using screws. There are two brackets in the file and they are unique for right and left (mirrored).

When installed you are able to quickly remove the monitor by unplugging it and slidding it up and out of the brackets. A great way to free up even more desk space while still being able to use a second monitor.

Designed in AutoDesk Fusion 360.

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Use 25% infill and 5 shells.

The high infill and shell count is used to reinforce the narrow spots. The narrowest spots are the most structural of the piece so spend the extra time to make them strong.

Support Removal

I found it is best to grab the supports with a pliers (see picture) and pull them out. If you try cutting them out or prying them out you are likely to break off the holding tabs.

Use a knife or file to clean up the support surfaces as needed to provide a friction fit.

title: Simple Lamp Design
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my simple lamp. I printed it on an reprap using ABS filament.
Have a look at the instructions for more information. Attention: Check if the lamp can stand the heat of the bulbs for a few hours. It works perfectly on my lamp but this depends on your lights and material. Feel free to fork the design.

Bill of Material:
  • 1x 19V notebook power supply or - 1x 12V power supply
  • 2x lamp holder G4
  • 2x light bulb G4 max.10W
  • 1x small switch
  • 1x set of printed parts
  • 4x m4x20 screws
    • Instructions
  • print parts
  • smoothen the surface by coating it with a thin layer of acetone
  • glue the lamp shade together
  • connect the power supply to the switch and light(s)
  • assemble the lamp holder
  • check if the lamp holder can stand the heat of the bulbs
  • mount the lamp holder on the base
  • put the lamp shade on the holder
  • check if the lamp can stand the heat of the bulbs for a few hours
  • ready!

title: Replicator 2 x - Active Cooling Fan Holder

description.text:
This support is to support temporary installation of a large FAN 90mm to ease PLA / PVA printing on a 2X. I can make changes to dimension upon request.   
Support bars fit into 2 FAN holes of 4mm size in diameter spaced by 83mm center to center and then the bar is

Just print ... Find the internal screw that is well hidden and press the support around it as shown in picture. The holder can then support the fan you insert onto the 2 horizontal bars. Simply remove when finished with PLA  
On my print I noticed that the tightening was a bit too much when I press in, I could relax a bit, but at end, still works fine. Let me know  
For the FAN I use an external power supply providing the correct voltage and with sufficient current (12V / 0.27A minim.). This does not take any risk to the 2X and the position is actually quite good during printing, I find.

title: TAZ5 E3D Titan Mount Remixed with stronger back and heat insert holes

description.text:
Update 081216: Spent a lot of time getting the blower fan for PLA dialed in. Completely restarted it from scratch and made to point as close to extrusion as possible While Not pointing to the heater block.

Also strengthened main mount to carriage even more down where the right angle supports come in and

Added 2 more pass thru holes and added fillet to all 3 holes for easy wire routing.

Note: The new fan duct WILL work on the last rev of the carriage mount.
Thanks!

Update 073116: Now Running E3D Titan Extruder and V6 Hot End

I wanted to print and use the version that @lasersharkdesign created but with a couple tweaks.

1) Moved/adjusted fan hole mounts for 3MM heat set inserts
2) Adjusted small holes for attaching the motor mount part to the main extruder mount using 2MM heat set inserts (yes super tiny :-)
3) Re-Created the fan shroud mount also for 3MM heat set inserts to mount fan to as well as made it thicker than the other shroud to print better and adhere to the mounting plate better when printing.

It's not in use yet, but will update as I get running. His design fit perfectly in the extruder / carriage mount on my TAZ 5.

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

description.text:
This is an apparatus designed to allow three people to conveniently type out a specific phrase: it is as it is
Each person must time their actions specifically, and operate their portion of the device with care.
This device was made to be a performance at a local art-event. Its operation is (of course) far from convenient, but it does type out the most true thing I have ever known.

I am sorry, but I did not take enough pictures, and in general, I am not sure if I could communicate how this device was built. I have included for you every part that I 3-d printed, as well as the .blend file, which contains a scale model of the typewriter, and all of the printed components in their functional positions. I do believe you would be able to reverse engineer the device by examining the .blend file. However, if their is interest, then I will do my best to draft a step by step set of build instructions. Some notes: The 3D parts with a letter in their title (S-gear.stl for example) correspond to the letter on the typewriter with which that part interacts. The exceptions are the parts with "L" or "R" in the title...those correspond with "Left" or "Right". Also note: "I-gear" and similar parts have two teeth side by side, but I ended up reducing that (with a saw) to one. To type out the word three people (or an individual with long arms) must use the two word handles, and the space bar presser with specific timing. The correct timing is as follows: Type 2 letters with the right handle, space bar, type one letter with the right handle, one letter with the left, space bar, type two letters with the left handle, space bar, and repeat. These openscad scripts were used: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5505 I have attached to this thing my (slightly) modified versions of the above scripts. sidenote: after re-reading these instructions...I don't see how any most of it will make sense to anybody.....sorry.

title: Starfarers of Catan Mothership Booster Skirt

description.text:
A 3D Printed skirt to replace the broken connectors on the mother ship in starfarers of catan. This skirt will attach to the original ship allowing you to use the original colored balls for movement.

The catch here is you must use a semi flexible or flexible filament. I originally printed these in PCTPE Nylon. But anything that is flexible should work fine. It is a TIGHT fit on the ship and the boosters will be a tight fit as well. Having this as a separate part should allow you to still remove the skirt and place the ships back in the box with no issues.

author: Mizunoslove

title: 3d Printed Clothing! Harry Potter Gryffindor Shirt!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So, it turns out you can 3d print RIGHT ON CLOTHING! NEAT!

Hello #PRINTERNETS!

I made this Gryffindor logo shirt by reworking the model done by Imminentfate.

After a bunch of trial and error, I've worked out the process!
3 first layers, at the least
Low heat
Lower layer height than .25
Use Avery Label Sheet (http://www.avery.com/avery/en_us/Products/Labels/Addressing-Labels/White-Mailing-Labels_05353.htm)
Cut out a sheet that is the size of the build plate.
Stick the sheet on the back side of the cloth.
Clip down the cloth (sheet side under) on all 4 corners, being sure that it is flat.
Re-level your build plate so that the nozzle just touches the cloth.
I have no idea how well it will stand up to the washing machine. (I suggest using fabric glue.)

As usual, here is the build video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P7F7GVWip18

See you next time!

print_settings.Notes:: You neither need supports, brims nor a raft to print the mount (given that your filament tacks well enough to the build plate). If you are printing without raft, you might however experience a slight elephant's foot (lowest layers of the print flaring out), which might prevent the mount to properly snap to the charger. Thus minor corrections with a utility knife or file might be required.

title: Nitecore D4 Battery Charger Wall Mount

description.text:
Here we have a wall mount for the Nitecore D4 Battery Charger. The mount gets attached to the wall with two 3.5 mm screws (length is up to you), and the charger perfectly snaps in. You need to drill two vertically aligned holes into your wall with a distance of 46 mm (no worries if the distance is slightly off, the screw holes in the mount have been designed with tolerance in mind; note that the first version I had uploaded had different screw hole distances between the flat and the tilted version, which now have been unified to 46 mm).

There is a flat version and a tilted version with 10° angle, which in my opinion is more convenient for inserting/removing the batteries and reading the display. The tilted version also has cut-outs for the power cord, in case you want to route the cord downwards behind the charger. Oh, and the tilted version coincidentally also works as desktop stand.

The SketchUp file includes a quite accurate model of the Nitecore D4 enclosure, which I created for reference.

See print settings below for details on how to print.

There is quite a bit of work in this, so if you print & like it, I'd be thankful for a small donation in EUR or USD: https://PayPal.Me/wookbert. Thanks a lot!

Printer:

CEL Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm Layerheight w/ 0.3 mm nozzle

Infill:

13%

Notes:

As you can see from the attached screenshot that wall mount is standing upright in the print layout. Because of this orientation related to the layers the clamps can't break off.

You neither need supports, brims nor a raft to print the mount (given that your filament tacks well enough to the build plate). If you are printing without raft, you might however experience a slight elephant's foot (lowest layers of the print flaring out), which might prevent the mount to properly snap to the charger. Thus minor corrections with a utility knife or file might be required.

remixed_from.title: HTC Vive sniper rifle controller for "The Nest"

title: HTC Vive sniper rifle controller for "The Nest" by Croccy22, modified by Alien Identity.Revision 3.

description.text:
For use with "The NEST" and the "Vive controller".

Rev 3, I think these parts will fit together and work.

I have tried to design the changes to hold the circular section of the Vive controller at 30 degrees below horizontal. I think that part # 4.9 will need to be removed to install the Vive controller in position, and when it is assembled the Vive controller should be captured. Part # 4,9 will need to be removed to free the Vive controller from the rifle.

If it works well for you please let me know, and if you find any problems tell me and I will see if I can make changes to help you to get the features you want.

I have added rounded edges to Part 5, and it is called Part5.3 and is now included in the parts list for this thing. I thought it may be more comfortable to use with radised edges to the rifle butt.

I have edited Part3, now called Part3.5 it has 5mm slots for the other parts to fit into. I have added Part 2, now called Part2.1. I have centered the slots and made all the slots 50mm wide, and all the tabs that fit into the slots are also 50mm wide.

I have included a jpeg image of the model to display what the modified thing looks like. The Vive controller used in the jpeg image of model was sourced from another design on thingiverse.... "HTC Vive Controller by Stien, published Mar 10, 2016"

Assembley. Requires 15 Button Head Socket Screws 1/4" UNC x 1-1/4 and 15 nuts to match. The bolts will need the length to be trimmed to fit flush with the nut.

The LÄMPLIG cooling rack from IKEA comes with four little rubber feet. However, ours kept falling out and disappearing, so I designed a replacement that snaps on firmly.

print_settings.Notes:: To ease up the printing process, the frame needed to be simple. Luckily my printer was able to handle all shapes without to much support material. The canopy can be printed completely without support. However the arms in V2 are a little complicated as they are hollow and the print tends to deform but it came out good enough for the first complete prototype.

description.text:
Note: I had to delay the design update because of the development of my printer and other things. I try to get up to this design with some nice new features as soon they are finished. :) Sorry for the delay.

  • Update: Version two with plenty of mechanical design changes coming soon. Designed for the Raspberry pi zero and cam.
  • Update! The redesign of version 2 will take a little longer due to deeper design changes for rigidity and component integration.

The purpose of this development was to gain knowledge in design and material strength and of course the fun factor to have a small FPV vehicle, inspired by the recent 250 race class. The focus wasn´t race performance as a CFK plate build is just more rigid than PLA. Instead I wanted more flight time to cruise around, or as base for more scientific operations such as mapping or inspection. The flight time happened to be around 17 minutes with a standard FPV cam, so I considered the whole construction as a success, regardless of the problems I discovered during testing..

I liked the idea to have an „exoskeleton“ , which is nothing new as this is standard in aviation and DJI phantoms or Microdrones etc build upon that concept. The main advantage seemed to be the more integrated look, aerodynamic, no need for CFK plates, complete in home production except for the electronics which led to more freedom from suppliers at least for the frame, protection for sensitive electronics inside and last but not least, freedom of design.

Printer:

Turnigy Fabrikator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20 - 50 %

Notes:

To ease up the printing process, the frame needed to be simple. Luckily my printer was able to handle all shapes without to much support material. The canopy can be printed completely without support. However the arms in V2 are a little complicated as they are hollow and the print tends to deform but it came out good enough for the first complete prototype.

comments.text: Love the design, probably print one myself, what I can't work out is how the top and bottom are joined and how you attached the battery and other stuff.Do you have any more pictures? and also, did you get it flying?

comments.text: Hey, thanks. There is a second version coming soon with a more practical design. On this version the canopy was screwed down to the standoffs with cutted threads and the first one had ca click mechanism that failed during flight. It flew ok but the arms were to flimsy. That has all been corrected in the newer version. I was busy with other projects and forgot the "work in progress".

title: Quick Change Filament Holder - Quick Print Too

description.text:
If you guys have any advice or request please comment and I'll try to help when possible!

Having bought my first 3D printer a month ago, this is my first part that I made. Designed using UG: NX 9.0

One can easily change between filaments without hastle. The build took approximately 6 hours total on my printer in "Standard" using Cura.

There is 1.5mm tolerance in the roller and side supports making it easy to change.
The sides reach 10mm into the roller for plenty of support.
Roller was accept any spool up to 64mm wide.
Since sides as basic as possible, it's easy to simply flex them out to pop the roller on or off for a filament change.

If you guys have any advice or request please comment and I'll try to help when possible!

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Parametric VR goggles for your mobile phone similar to Google Cardboard.

Provided STL Parts

The provided STL parts are configured for use with:

  • iPhone 5
  • 25 mm dia. x 45 mm focal len. x 4.65 mm thick @ center (Cardboard v1 lenses)
  • ~60 mm long M4 machine screws

The QR code for the VR profile is included as an image. If you change the parameters you should create your own profile.

Printing Tips

The spacer has a couple of overhangs that violate the 45 degree rule. You'll have to use support for that part or be willing to clean up some mess. I opted to clean up the mess and it wasn't bad with a cordless drill and some wire cutters.

Extra Parts

Requires two nuts and bolts.

print_settings.Notes:: Print diffuser at 100% if you want it clear. It was printed transparent so you can still slightly see the notification light, you can either avoid printing it, print it in clear, or print it in any color and ignore the light. For the small top lights, I printed 3 at a time and printed on a raft to give each piece time between cooling, then you can pick the best of the three. This may not be necessary depending on your printer.

title: Galaxy S5 Pokedex Phone Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a multi-part Pokedex phone case for the Samsung Galaxy S5. All parts are separate files so that you can print each part in its own color. Fits snugly enough so that turning it upside down will not easily release the phone, but can be taken out via the charging port cutout. All ports, including the headphone jack, are accessible in open and closed configuration

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Z18

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Print diffuser at 100% if you want it clear. It was printed transparent so you can still slightly see the notification light, you can either avoid printing it, print it in clear, or print it in any color and ignore the light. For the small top lights, I printed 3 at a time and printed on a raft to give each piece time between cooling, then you can pick the best of the three. This may not be necessary depending on your printer.

Assembly

Press top lights into lightpad. Glue the top light circle and diffuser into top pad. Then glue top pad onto base, aligning edges.

Glue all buttons and screens into lid, turn over and glue triangle(or paint, your choice)

To connect lid and base, use standard 1.75mm filament. I use a soldering iron to melt the filament ends and fuse them to the body, however you could easily put a drop of glue into the ends after inserting and it should do well enough.

Insert phone and enjoy hunting pokemon!

Attach top belt and walk around town with hands free water bottles. Peace out!   :)

title: Clip on water bottle tote for the hippies...

description.text:
This is the same water bottle tote that attaches to your belt loop except the base support for the bottle forms the "peace" sign (or a chicken foot if you happen to just love chickens). I modified the latest version of the base file. It prints in two parts. The fit is snug so simply rub both connecting pieces with acetone (nail polish remover). Once assembled, I usually rub a bit more acetone on the top and bottom of the connections to provide a stronger bond. Add a ring from a key ring and a simple carabiner so you can hang from your belt loop.

NOTE: Not all water bottles are created equally. I found that the bottles from Costco (Kirkland brand) are slightly larger at the base and do not slide in easily. The inner diameter of the tote is 67mm (~2.64 inches). You may want to scale the stl file up a percent or two to make it more universal.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:

The base requires no supports. The top portion will print fine without supports but prints a bit better if you add a support or two for the arch where the ring attaches.

Print the two parts. Wipe the inside opening on the top portion with acetone, dip the top of the rod for the lower portion in acetone and press together. Wipe additional acetone on top of and below the two pieces and hold until set. Run ring through the hoop and connect the carabiner clip. Attach top belt and walk around town with hands free water bottles. Peace out! :)

print_settings.Notes:: The design is symmetric, so left and right side door knobs work with the same stl file.  Slightly better aesthetics are obtained by orienting the design so that the side which prints down will face toward the door.

title: Ergonomic Door Knob Lever, Fully Parametric

description.text:
This is an adapter to convert a round door knob to a door handle with a lever, inspired by the design by tbirdrv. I redid this concept from scratch in OpenSCAD so that the dimensions can be fully parameterized to fit various door knob sizes with a close match so that the pieces line up.

I am fond of smooth ergonomic 3D printed parts, so this design calculates a curved hand-friendly structure with smooth rounded edges. This results in additional calculation time for OpenSCAD to render the final result. If you turn the sfn parameter down to 0, then it will render quickly for adjusting dimensions. I recommend raising it back to 4 for the final render for a smooth result.

The most elegant resulting appearance is obtained if you match the nom_knob_diam variable in the .scad file to within at least 0.3mm of the correct diameter for your door knob. Calipers and good calibration are helpful for this, otherwise you may have to adjust and reprint. You can also try terminating a test print early, and using the first few layers to check your measurement. At the ideal size the nut and bolt sides will clamp together tightly right as it reaches the desired grip on the door knob.

The example stl file is for a 54.8mm diameter door knob, and is designed to be held on with an M5x12 bolt and an M5 nut.

Note: The OpenSCAD file uses my threading library for creating the properly sized recessed bolt and nut holes. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686322

Installation tip: If you printed just a tiny amount too wide, or you want to increase the grip on the door knob, then try stretching a very thin strip of standard poster putty around the door knob before mounting the lever around it. This will significantly increase the coefficient of friction between the two surfaces, in a removable way, and give it a sturdy hold without needing to excessively tighten the lever around the knob.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-11

Resolution:

0.5 x/y, 0.2 z, 1.5 perimeter, 1.0 top/bottom

Infill:

50%-100%

Notes:

Using solid infill can provide added strength for handling the leverage that can be applied to this part when installed on a door. Also if you use PLA, and sometimes print a little low in temperature, increase your temperature a little (at least 210C) for this print to avoid delamination under the strains this is normally used at.

The design is symmetric, so left and right side door knobs work with the same stl file. Slightly better aesthetics are obtained by orienting the design so that the side which prints down will face toward the door.

remixed_from.author: thingirob
remixed_from.title: Tevo Tarantula Modular X Car Basic, e3d 2x

title: Tevo Tarantula Direct E3D Titan X-Carriage

description.text:
This is Direct Feed Titan Extruder X-Carriage designed to work the the Tevo Tarantula.

This was designed to work specifically with an E3Dv6 Hotend, E3D Titan Extruder, and a Nema 17 Pancake Stepper motor (Link below to dimensions and specs)

Features:

  • Extruder Direct Feed setup lowered to clear the 2040 Tarantula X Rail
  • Currently support standard E3D Heatblock BLTouch, SN04 (Stock) and Round Proximity Sensors
  • 3 Wheeled design to allow the stepper motor drop to the correct height and allows easier tensioning of wheels against X beam
  • Reinforcement beams with integrated cable tie slots (belt lock version)
  • 2 Versions:

    X Belt locking mechanism (by thingirob) - eliminate the use of zip ties to secure X belt
    X Belt Fine Adjustment Version (modeled from Ulmenkott) - provides fine adjustment of X belt tension

IMPORTANT: Because the endstop was relocated, you will need to make a few changes in your firmware and hardware. The following changes were done using Marlin 1.1 RC7 & MKS Base 1.2:

  1. Uncomment define USE_XMAX_PLUG
  2. Changed X_HOME_DIR from -1 to 1
  3. Moved the connector on the MKS board from -X to +X

ADDITIONAL: May need this as well. Thanks xfirax for the heads up!

define X_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING false // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop

X & Y Probe Offset(s):

BLTouch:
X Probe offset from nozzle: 20mm
Y Probe offset from nozzle: 65mm

SN04:
X Probe offset from nozzle: 20mm
Y Probe offset from nozzle: 75mm

Round:
X Probe offset from nozzle: 20mm
Y Probe offset from nozzle: 90mm

NOTE: I've included the native 123D Design formats so you can modify if required / desired. Keeping this open source to hopefully encourage improvements and new designs.

In development:

  • 8.5mm spacer for Volcano Heatblock
  • Integrated Layer Fan mount & Fan to eliminate the need for the E3D Hotend Fan to be used as a mounting point

Special Thanks: This is a remix of thingirob's Tevo Tarantula Modular X Car Basic, e3d 2x
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438795) as well as using Ulmenkott belt tensioner idea (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1640682). Without their designs it would of been difficult to create this remix.

Relavant Links:
E3Dv6 Hotend - http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6
E3D Titan Extuder - http://e3d-online.com/Titan-Extruder
Nema 17 Pancake Motor - http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/nema-17-bipolar-step-motor-35v-1a-13ncm184ozin-17hs081004s-p-101.html

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

85

Notes:

Printed with PETG.

remixed_from.author: gianteye
remixed_from.title: The Glaucus: A soft robot quadruped

title: The Glaucus: A soft robot quadruped

description.text:
This is the current Thingiverse page for the development of the Glaucus soft robot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:277171), originally designed by Matthew Borgatti of Super-Releaser (http://superreleaser.com). This page contains information regarding past, present, and future iterations of the Glaucus along with pictures and CAD.

Glaucus 1.0 Video: http://youtu.be/RCEzuPKgK6c
Glaucus 1.0 Guide: http://learn.adafruit.com/soft-quadruped-robot-glaucus
Glaucus 1.0 Super-Releaser Forum Page: http://forum.superreleaser.com/viewtopic.php?f=1&t=16

Glaucus 1.0

Smooth-sil 935 is by weight and not by volume

  • Overly thick smooth-sil causes uneven castings for the bathtub tooling, making even clamping pressure difficult
    Vacuum chamber is necessary
  • Bubble displacement in limited cure time (sans retardant) is difficult
  • Vibration is an option instead of vacuum for degassing
    The molds should be made out of Smooth-Sil, not Ecoflex
  • The Ecoflex is too soft for casting in, and the Ecoflex can stick to itself during casting
    Waxes need to be thoroughly cleaned
  • There should be detailed images of what a fully cleaned wax looks like on the tutorial
  • Add go/no go gauge for the wax, to determine if the deformation of the wax or shrinkage of the wax is not appropriate to continue building
  • Better instructions for truing the waxes
  • Need to update dewaxing process to a new hot-oil method
    Detailed information on volumes of molds is necessary for mixing
  • Include volumes or material weight measurements in tutorial
  • Body bathtub castings total 1600g
  • Wax bathtub castings total 1600g
    Casting must be free from large voids or bubbles
  • The first casting can be repaired by opening up the mold after the first eco-flex casting, using nail scissors to open up any bubbles that are near the surface, and pouring newly mixed EcoFlex to seal them. After this layer has gelled the mold can be assembled with the final half of the glaucus and re-poured.
    Eco-Flex is curing before displacing all bubbles
  • Need timing to be more precisely outlined
  • Working in a cold place will increase cure times
  • Cure retardant can also help
    Molds are filling slowly
  • Silicone oil or silicone thinner can be added in up to 10% by weight to reduce viscosity
  • Also, can add up to ¼” air ducts between legs in both sides of molds; okay if they fill with Ecoflex
    No description of how to control it to make it walk is in the existing instruction
    Glaucus needs thicker walls all over
    Need tips for how to cut the back end more smoothly to have a good seal to the 3D printed part
    Total cost of materials is high
    Add the tool of the heat sensor so mold temperature is consistent
    Need to write a justification for some decision making or underscore why these parts are chosen as appropriate
    Need description of the luer fittings in addition to the link

description.text:
A fun little robot that prints in one complete piece. Both the arms and legs move. I made him to put in my son's party bags. Robot Mk8 is a work in progress but is fun to play with right now. His feet are compatible with lego bricks.

He stands 60 mm tall from tip of antenna to bottom of feet.

I plan to make more dials for his chest and maybe make his head and hands turn.

Inspired by jcubed111's Robot Keychain Accessory http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384213

Update: 10th September 2016
Added a model for a 4 times taller robot. He's 298 grams and takes ~12 hours to print at 350 micron resolution. I didn't scale the fit of the movable limbs so they are all very floppy but he still stands up. He gets a lot of attention. If anyone has trouble with limbs sticking on the original scale version, I recommend scaling the model up a little. That should do the trick if fiddling with the fit parameters is getting you nowhere.

Update: 7th August 2016

  1. Added option for random dial needle angle (set to -1). Angles between -28 and +28 degrees work well.
  2. Added option for hole for key ring. Hole size not changeable with customizer yet.
  3. Added rotating head joint.

author: RolandJuno

description.text:
This is a robot that can catch the balls you throw at it, using computer vision. It uses two PS3 Eye cameras to triangulate the ball's position, and moves a Cartesian coordinate robot accordingly.

The robot and its software was developed by a team of four high school students, in two and a half weeks, at Rose Hulman's "Operation Catapult" Engineering program. It won the Best Project Award.

The robot's design was inspired by the mechanics of generic 3D printers and CNC machines, but was designed fully from scratch.

Note: The included STL file is a CAD design of all the pieces composing the robot, combined together. Some of the shown pieces are 3D printed (the mounts, brackets, etc.), some are laser cut (the frame), and some are purchased (steppers, smooth rods, etc.).

More information can be found here: https://barancode.com/projects/catchbot/

description.text:
A handfull of collets for things 16682 and/or 16890 !
The ZIP file contains 48 STL to accomodate the drill bits I use the most.
As you can see, there's also collets for hex bits, size 6.25mm face to face.
They work fairly well, check out the pic with the piece of wood, it's a 15mm thick piece of oak and I have been able to go through it with the 1mm bit ! yes, it took me a while ;-)

Get the collet you need from the ZIP file or use the OpenSCAD script to generate another one with a different size.
Metric sizes only -sorry- 1mm 1.5mm 2mm 2.5mm 3mm 3.2mm 3.5mm 4mm 4.5mm 4.8mm 5mm 6mm 6.5mm and 8mm
Everything is provided with 3 different gap/tolerance values: 0.10, 0.25 and 0.50 mm
The OpenSCAD has not been much tested, some features are not even finish... oups!
Anyway, for drill bits (cylindrical) and hex bits should work quite fine.

description.text: This is a box to house a DROK variable USB load device. Not fancy, but functional. I purchased the device on Amazon. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B016EYMVX4

Printer:

QiDi

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used 0.2 / layer with MG PLA

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

I used 5 top, 5 bottom, and 5 outside layers. As the walls are only 1mm thick that will just about fill the bill.

This was a quick and dirty design job

If I had taken the time to do an angled roof section rather than a 90 degree roof next to the fan I think this object would have printed with no supports. That would have saved a lot of time spent on the post print removal of the interior supports. If I ever need another one I will do it.

So, remove the supports, pop off the two knobs, angle the device into the enclosure, and pop the knobs back on. I did not do anything to tie this thing into the box as its a close fit. I did add a small piece of double-sided mastic (foam tape) under the device's USB tang to hold the bottom onto that area.

If you want to tweak, have fun...

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b0Z1aXg4Wy0

title: Geared MOTORs to Meccano and Lego Conversion - Kit Parts - UPDATED - AXLES and PEGS

description.text:
This is a Conversion Kit for the Yellow TT Motors off of ebay - is for connecting to Meccano and Lego Parts. This allows the user to easily create Motorized Cars, Vehicles; Remote Control Automotans; and automated Robots - etc.

The Kit assumes usage of my already designed Meccano Parts - from here or other of my Meccano Parts Pages.

The Conversion Parts specifically are the Gears and Wheels - with the Moon-Cut Circle to plug onto the Motor. These have Holes compatible with Lego 16-tooth Gears and the Lego X-Axles. There are alternate Dual Holes to screw onto Meccano Rods.

The Conversion Parts:

  • Converter Peg - converts Motor Moon Axle to Lego Technic X-Axle.
  • Gear Base - converts Motor to 16-Tooth Gear without Teeth - just Lego Holes.
  • Gear - converts Motor to Lego Gear.
  • Mecc Peg - converts Motor to Meccano Holes.

These Parts are under Planar and Extended Axle Forms.

Also are the Front and Back Motor-Mount Parts that act as sleeves to place over the ends of the specific Motors listed above. Meccano Parts can then be screw mounted on them for projects.

Additionally are added: two Axles. One Axle/Motor is to match the Motor Beveled axle - to allow adding of free rolling Wheels without the use of a Motor. Second Axle/Peg is meant to be cut into pieces - and act as a Parts Connector without the use of Screws or Bolts. Note, to use the Wheels Axle - the user will need to drill a larger Hole into the Wheel Axle Part.

Screws 1/2inch #4 or #6 are also needed - else M2 or M3 Bolts.

Some simple example projects are pictured that my daughter built: a Dragster, and a Walking Duck. They are automated by wiring the Motors to old toy truck Remote Controllers. And yes, the Duck walks - by rotating Legs , pretty well actually - that which my daughter built.

Have Fun !

If you build this, then deffinately refer to Meccano Base Parts Plates Struts Angles - for additional parts.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.8mm Nozzle Tips

Notes:

I printed these on a Mendel RepRap with 1.75mm fibre. I used a 0.8mm Nozzle Tip with 0.5mm Layer Height setting. Can use any tip from 0.2mm to 0.8mm should print fine. It took between 3-10 minutes per part to print. - Backbone and Belly Ring should be Rotated 90-degrees to have ball-round surface upon the Table to print properly. - Rafts are suggested for these. - Parts may be a little thin and fragile - so be careful when removing.

Some Parts may have burrs -and need filing to finish.
Holes may need to be drilled if the Legos are tight.
If the bolts seem loose, gluegun may help.
Used TinkerCad.

title: Bleackburn Flea Bike Light Handlebar Mount - 22.2mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Handlebar clamp mount for Blackburn Flea bike headlight. The inner diameter is 24mm to accommodate some rubber padding, so just cut up a piece of an old tube or something and mount it!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

This requires a little bit of work after printing:

First, the hinge hole is small and I used 16gauge steel wire as a hinge pin, so I had to drill the hold out a little. Best done with a drill-press, but you can make do without.

Next, the light clip itself is a separate part from the clamp. I designed it this way both to avoid using rafts and supports, and to align the layers for best possible strength.

I welded the clip onto the clamp using a soldering iron and extra filament, but if you have a good solvent/glue it would probably be strong enough. I also used an x-acto knife to open up the space the clip fits into because tolerance of my print was not where I expected.

Finally, get a 5/16" hex nut and machine screw, and put it on your bike!

All minerals fall into one of six crystal classes based on the ordering of their component elements and polyatomic ions.  
Isometric, a=b=c, alpha=beta=gamma=90 degrees  
Tetragonal: a=b<>c, alpha, beta, and gamma equal 90 degrees  
Orthorhombic: a, b, and c are unequal; alpha, beta, and gamma equal 90 degrees; a=20, b=30, c=40  
Hexagonal: a=b<>c; alpha=beta=90 degrees, gamma=120 degrees;  
Monoclinic, a, b, and c are unequal; alpha and gamma = 90 degrees, beta does not equalÃÂ 90 degrees  
Triclinic: a,b, and c are unequal; neither alpha, norÃÂ beta, norÃÂ gamma equalÃÂ 90 degrees

title: Motorized ROBOTICS ARM CLAW Kit - Meccano Lego Compatible Parts - UPDATED Axles Converter

description.text:
This is a set of Struts that I composed. These are 3D shaped , in contrast to the Meccano Parts that are 2D in that they are Flat / paper-like based. They are still compatible with the Meccano and Motor Converter Parts that I posted here on other Pages.

Parts included are: Motor Gear Mounts, Motor Mounting Sleeves, Jaws, ClawNails, Feet, Curves, etc.

An assortment of Functional Models are listed via Images above.

These are compatible with the Meccano and Motor Parts (as mentioned earlier) , including:

  • Meccano Base Parts Plates Struts Angles ,
  • Geared MOTORs to Meccano and Lego Conversion - Kit Parts

for additional parts.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.8mm Nozzle Tips

Notes:

I printed these on a Mendel RepRap with 1.75mm fibre. I used a 0.8mm Nozzle Tip with 0.5mm Layer Height setting. Can use any tip from 0.2mm to 0.8mm should print fine. It took between 3-10 minutes per part to print. - Backbone and Belly Ring should be Rotated 90-degrees to have ball-round surface upon the Table to print properly. - Rafts are suggested for these. - Parts may be a little thin and fragile - so be careful when removing.

Some Parts may have burrs -and need filing to finish.
Holes may need to be drilled if the Legos are tight.
If the bolts seem loose, gluegun may help.

Used TinkerCad.
Built this with my custom Meccano Parts.
